The **Atlanta Falcons** are a professional [American
football](/wiki/American_football "American football") team based in [Atlanta,
Georgia](/wiki/Atlanta "Atlanta"). The Falcons compete in the [National
Football League](/wiki/National_Football_League "National Football League")
(NFL) as a member club of the league's [National Football
Conference](/wiki/National_Football_Conference "National Football Conference")
(NFC) [South](/wiki/NFC_South "NFC South") division. The Falcons joined the
NFL in 1965[2] as an [expansion team](/wiki/Expansion_team "Expansion team"),
after the NFL offered then-owner [Rankin Smith](/wiki/Rankin_Smith "Rankin
Smith") a franchise to keep him from joining the rival [American Football
League](/wiki/American_Football_League "American Football League") (AFL).

In their 51 years of existence, the Falcons have compiled a record of
350–450–6 (341–437–6 in the regular season and 9–13 in the playoffs), winning
division championships in 1980, 1998, 2004, 2010, 2012, and 2016. The Falcons
have appeared in two [Super Bowls](/wiki/Super_Bowl "Super Bowl"), the first
being during the 1998 season in [Super Bowl XXXIII](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXXIII
"Super Bowl XXXIII"), where they lost to the [Denver
Broncos](/wiki/Denver_Broncos "Denver Broncos") 34–19,[3] and the second being
a 34–28 overtime defeat by the [New England
Patriots](/wiki/New_England_Patriots "New England Patriots") in [Super Bowl
LI](/wiki/Super_Bowl_LI "Super Bowl LI").

The Falcons played their home games at the [Georgia Dome](/wiki/Georgia_Dome
"Georgia Dome") in [downtown Atlanta](/wiki/Downtown_Atlanta "Downtown
Atlanta") from the 1992 to 2016 NFL seasons. Construction began on [Mercedes-
Benz Stadium](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_Stadium "Mercedes-Benz Stadium") in May
2014, and play began there in the 2017 season. Their headquarters and practice
facilities are located at a 50-acre site in [Flowery Branch,
Georgia](/wiki/Flowery_Branch,_Georgia "Flowery Branch, Georgia").[4]

## Franchise
history[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Atlanta_Falcons&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Franchise history")]

For more details on this topic, see [History of the Atlanta
Falcons](/wiki/History_of_the_Atlanta_Falcons "History of the Atlanta
Falcons").

### Professional football comes to
Atlanta[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Atlanta_Falcons&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Professional football comes to Atlanta")]

Professional football first came to Atlanta in 1962, when the [American
Football League](/wiki/American_Football_League "American Football League")
staged two preseason contests, with one featuring the [Denver
Broncos](/wiki/Denver_Broncos "Denver Broncos") vs. the [Houston
Oilers](/wiki/History_of_the_Houston_Oilers "History of the Houston Oilers")
and the second pitting the [Dallas Texans](/wiki/Dallas_Texans_\(AFL\) "Dallas
Texans \(AFL\)") against the [Oakland Raiders](/wiki/Oakland_Raiders "Oakland
Raiders"). Two years later, the [AFL](/wiki/American_Football_League "American
Football League") held another exhibition, this time with the [New York
Jets](/wiki/New_York_Jets "New York Jets") taking on the [San Diego
Chargers](/wiki/San_Diego_Chargers "San Diego Chargers").

In 1965, after the [Atlanta–Fulton County
Stadium](/wiki/Atlanta%E2%80%93Fulton_County_Stadium "Atlanta–Fulton County
Stadium") (then known simply as Atlanta Stadium) was built, the city of
Atlanta felt the time was right to start pursuing professional football. One
independent group which had been active in NFL exhibition promotions in
Atlanta applied for franchises in both the [American Football
League](/wiki/American_Football_League "American Football League") and the
[National Football League](/wiki/National_Football_League "National Football
League"), acting entirely on its own with no guarantee of stadium rights.
Another group reported it had deposited earnest money for a team in the
AFL.[5]

With everyone running in different directions, some local businessmen worked
out a deal and were awarded an AFL franchise on June 7, 1965, contingent upon
acquiring exclusive stadium rights from city officials. NFL Commissioner Pete
Rozelle, who had been moving slowly in Atlanta matters, was spurred by the AFL
interest and headed on the next plane down to Atlanta to block the rival
league's claim on the city of Atlanta.[2] He forced the city to make a choice
between the two leagues. By June 30, the city picked Rankin Smith and the NFL.

The Atlanta Falcons franchise began on June 30, 1965, when [NFL
Commissioner](/wiki/NFL_Commissioner "NFL Commissioner") [Pete
Rozelle](/wiki/Pete_Rozelle "Pete Rozelle") granted ownership to 41-year-old
[Rankin Smith Sr.](/wiki/Rankin_Smith_Sr. "Rankin Smith Sr.") Smith, an
Executive Vice President of Life Insurance Company of Georgia at the time,
paid $8.5 million the highest price in NFL history at the time for a
franchise.[2] Former commissioner Pete Rozelle and Smith made the deal in
about five minutes and the Atlanta Falcons brought the largest and most
popular sport to the city of Atlanta. The Atlanta expansion franchise became
the 15th NFL franchise, and they were awarded the first pick in the [1966 NFL
draft](/wiki/1966_NFL_draft "1966 NFL draft") as well as the final pick in
each of the first five rounds.[6] The Falcons drafted [All-
American](/wiki/All-American "All-American") [linebacker](/wiki/Linebacker
"Linebacker") [Tommy Nobis](/wiki/Tommy_Nobis "Tommy Nobis") from the
[University of Texas](/wiki/Texas_Longhorns_football "Texas Longhorns
football") with the first pick of the [draft](/wiki/1966_NFL_draft "1966 NFL
draft"), making him the first-ever Falcon. The
[league](/wiki/National_Football_League "National Football League") also held
the [1966 NFL Expansion Draft](/wiki/1966_NFL_Expansion_Draft "1966 NFL
Expansion Draft") six weeks later in which the Falcons selected unprotected
players from existing franchises. Although the Falcons selected many good
players in those drafts, they still were not able to win right away.[2]

The Atlanta Falcons Football Club received its nickname on August 29, 1965.
Miss Julia Elliott, a school teacher from [Griffin,
Georgia](/wiki/Griffin,_Georgia "Griffin, Georgia"), was singled out from many
people who suggested "Falcons" as the nickname for the new franchise. Elliott
wrote: "the Falcon is proud and dignified, with great courage and fight. It
never drops its prey. It is deadly and has a great sporting tradition."[7][8]

### 1966–1977: Early
struggles[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Atlanta_Falcons&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: 1966–1977: Early struggles")]

The Falcons had their first season in [1966](/wiki/1966_NFL_season "1966 NFL
season"), and their first preseason game on August 1, 1966, losing to the
[Philadelphia Eagles](/wiki/Philadelphia_Eagles "Philadelphia Eagles"). Under
head coach [Norb Hecker](/wiki/Norb_Hecker "Norb Hecker") they lost their
first nine regular-season games in 1966 and secured their first victory on the
road against the [New York Giants](/wiki/New_York_Giants "New York Giants").
The team finished the 1960s with only 12 wins. The Falcons had their first
[Monday Night Football](/wiki/Monday_Night_Football "Monday Night Football")
game in Atlanta during the [1970](/wiki/1970_NFL_season "1970 NFL season")
season, losing 20–7 to the [Miami Dolphins](/wiki/Miami_Dolphins "Miami
Dolphins"). The only two winning seasons in this twelve-year period were 1971
and 1973.

### 1978–1989[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Atlanta_Falcons&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: 1978–1989")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/1987_Atlanta_Falcons_Pocket_Schedule.jpg/220px-1987_Atlanta_Falcons_Pocket_Schedule.jpg)](/wiki/File:1987_Atlanta_Falcons_Pocket_Schedule.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:1987_Atlanta_Falcons_Pocket_Schedule.jpg "Enlarge")

The Falcons' defense taking on [Denver Broncos](/wiki/Denver_Broncos "Denver
Broncos") quarterback [John Elway](/wiki/John_Elway "John Elway") during a
1985 game.

In the 1978 season, the Falcons qualified for the playoffs for the first time
and won the Wild Card game against the Eagles 14–13. The following week, they
lost to the [Dallas Cowboys](/wiki/Dallas_Cowboys "Dallas Cowboys") 27–20 in
the Divisional Playoffs.

In the 1980 season, after a nine-game winning streak, the Falcons posted a
franchise then-best record of 12–4 and captured their first NFC West division
title. The next week, their dream season ended at home with a loss to the
Cowboys 30–27 in the divisional playoffs. In the strike-shortened 1982 season,
the Falcons made the playoffs but lost to the [Minnesota
Vikings](/wiki/Minnesota_Vikings "Minnesota Vikings"), 30–24. Falcons coach
[Leeman Bennett](/wiki/Leeman_Bennett "Leeman Bennett") was fired after the
loss. The team would then have losing seasons for the next eight years.

### 1989–1996[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Atlanta_Falcons&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: 1989–1996")]

In 1989, the Falcons drafted cornerback [Deion Sanders](/wiki/Deion_Sanders
"Deion Sanders") in the first round, who helped them for the next four years,
setting many records for the franchise. "Neon Deion" (a.k.a. "Prime Time") had
a flashy appeal and helped bring media attention to one of the league's most
anonymous franchises. Sanders was also famous for playing on major league
baseball teams ([the New York Yankees](/wiki/The_New_York_Yankees "The New
York Yankees") and the [Atlanta Braves](/wiki/Atlanta_Braves "Atlanta
Braves")) while simultaneously playing in the NFL.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Atlanta_Falcons_at_Los_Angeles_Rams_1991-12-08_-_01_%28Atlanta_Falcons_crop%29.jpg/220px-
Atlanta_Falcons_at_Los_Angeles_Rams_1991-12-08_-_01_%28Atlanta_Falcons_crop%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Atlanta_Falcons_at_Los_Angeles_Rams_1991-12-08_-_01_\(Atlanta_Falcons_crop\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Atlanta_Falcons_at_Los_Angeles_Rams_1991-12-08_-_01_\(Atlanta_Falcons_crop\).jpg
"Enlarge")

The Falcons playing against the [Los Angeles Rams](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Rams "Los
Angeles Rams") during a 1991 away game.

After defeating the [New Orleans Saints](/wiki/New_Orleans_Saints "New Orleans
Saints") in the NFC Wild Card game, the Falcons' 1991 season ended in a
divisional playoff loss to the [Washington Redskins](/wiki/Washington_Redskins
"Washington Redskins"). In 1991, the Falcons drafted [Brett
Favre](/wiki/Brett_Favre "Brett Favre") as the thirty-third overall pick.
During his rookie season, he played in two games where he amassed a record of
4 passing attempts with 0 receptions and 2 interceptions. The following
February, Favre was traded to the [Green Bay Packers](/wiki/Green_Bay_Packers
"Green Bay Packers").

In 1992, the Atlanta Falcons opened a new chapter in their history moving into
the newly constructed Georgia Dome, where the team has defeated all 31 other
NFL teams at least during its time there.

### 1997–2000: The Dan Reeves
era[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Atlanta_Falcons&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: 1997–2000: The Dan Reeves era")]

In 1998, under recently acquired head coach [Dan Reeves](/wiki/Dan_Reeves "Dan
Reeves"), quarterback [Chris Chandler](/wiki/Chris_Chandler "Chris Chandler")
and running back [Jamal Anderson](/wiki/Jamal_Anderson "Jamal Anderson") the
"Dirty Bird" Falcons had their greatest season to date. On November 8, they
beat the [New England Patriots](/wiki/New_England_Patriots "New England
Patriots") 41–10, ending a streak of 22 losses at cold-weather sites. The team
finished with a franchise-best 14–2 regular season record and the NFC West
division championship. On January 17, 1999, the Falcons upset the top-seeded
Vikings at the [Hubert H. Humphrey
Metrodome](/wiki/Hubert_H._Humphrey_Metrodome "Hubert H. Humphrey Metrodome")
in the [NFC Championship Game](/wiki/NFC_Championship_Game "NFC Championship
Game") 30–27, in an exciting overtime victory. However, in their first-ever
Super Bowl appearance, they lost 34–19 to the defending champion [Denver
Broncos](/wiki/Denver_Broncos "Denver Broncos") in [Super Bowl
XXXIII](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXXIII "Super Bowl XXXIII").

In the second game of the Falcons 1999 season, running back [Jamal
Anderson](/wiki/Jamal_Anderson "Jamal Anderson"), who had been a key player in
the Falcons' 1998 success, suffered a season-ending knee injury. The Falcons
finished the season with a very disappointing 5–11 regular season record.[2]
In 2000, the Falcons suffered through another horrendous season finishing 4–12
and once again missing the playoffs.

### 2001–2006[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Atlanta_Falcons&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: 2001–2006")]

In the [2001 NFL draft](/wiki/2001_NFL_draft "2001 NFL draft"), the Falcons
orchestrated a trade with the [San Diego Chargers](/wiki/San_Diego_Chargers
"San Diego Chargers"), acquiring the first overall pick (which was used on
quarterback [Michael Vick](/wiki/Michael_Vick "Michael Vick")) in exchange for
wide receiver-return specialist [Tim Dwight](/wiki/Tim_Dwight "Tim Dwight")
and the fifth overall pick (used on running back [LaDainian
Tomlinson](/wiki/LaDainian_Tomlinson "LaDainian Tomlinson")).

The Falcons finished the [2001 season](/wiki/2001_Atlanta_Falcons_season "2001
Atlanta Falcons season") with a record of 7–9 and missed the playoffs. [Jessie
Tuggle](/wiki/Jessie_Tuggle "Jessie Tuggle") retired following 14 seasons in
Atlanta. On December 6, 2001, [Arthur M. Blank](/wiki/Arthur_M._Blank "Arthur
M. Blank") reached a preliminary agreement with the Falcons' Taylor Smith to
purchase the team. In a special meeting prior to [Super Bowl
XXXVI](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXXVI "Super Bowl XXXVI") in New Orleans on February
2, 2002, NFL owners voted unanimously to approve the purchase.[9]

The 2002 season saw the Falcons return to the playoffs with a regular season
record of 9–6–1, tying the [Pittsburgh Steelers](/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers
"Pittsburgh Steelers"). It was Vick's first year as the starter, and the team,
with newly acquired running back Warrick Dunn, delivered the Green Bay Packers
their first home playoff loss ever. A 20-6 loss to the [Donovan
McNabb](/wiki/Donovan_McNabb "Donovan McNabb")-led Philadelphia Eagles the
following week, however, ended the Falcons' season.

On March 19, 2003, the Falcons presented their new logo.[10][2] During the
2003 preseason Vick broke his leg and missed the first twelve games of the
season. After losing 7 straight games, the decision was made to release head
coach Dan Reeves. [Wade Phillips](/wiki/Wade_Phillips "Wade Phillips") acted
as interim coach for the final 3 games. Although the Falcons won 3 of their
last 4 games after the return of Vick, they ended up with a 5–11 record that
year. In 2004, a new head coach, [Jim L. Mora](/wiki/Jim_L._Mora "Jim L.
Mora"), was hired and Vick returned for the [full
season](/wiki/2004_Atlanta_Falcons_season "2004 Atlanta Falcons season"). The
Falcons went 11–5, winning their third division title and earning a first-
round bye into the playoffs. In the divisional playoffs, the Falcons defeated
the [St. Louis Rams](/wiki/2004_St._Louis_Rams_season "2004 St. Louis Rams
season"), 47–17, in the [Georgia Dome](/wiki/Georgia_Dome "Georgia Dome"),
advancing to the [NFC Championship Game](/wiki/NFC_Championship_Game "NFC
Championship Game"), which they lost to the
[Eagles](/wiki/2004_Philadelphia_Eagles_season "2004 Philadelphia Eagles
season"), 27–10.

The [Falcons](/wiki/2005_Atlanta_Falcons_season "2005 Atlanta Falcons season")
again fell short of achieving back-to-back winning seasons in
[2005](/wiki/2005_NFL_season "2005 NFL season"), going 8–8. In
[2006](/wiki/2006_NFL_season "2006 NFL season"), Michael Vick became the first
quarterback in league history to rush for more than 1,000 yards in a season,
with 1,039. After finishing the season 7–9, however, coach Jim Mora was
dismissed and [Bobby Petrino](/wiki/Bobby_Petrino "Bobby Petrino"), the
[University of Louisville](/wiki/University_of_Louisville "University of
Louisville")'s football coach, replaced him. Before the
[2007](/wiki/2007_NFL_season "2007 NFL season") season began, Vick was
suspended indefinitely by the NFL after pleading guilty to charges involving
dog fighting in the state of Virginia. On December 10, 2007, Vick received a
23-month prison sentence and was officially cut from the Atlanta roster.

### 2007[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Atlanta_Falcons&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: 2007")]

Main article: [2007 Atlanta Falcons season](/wiki/2007_Atlanta_Falcons_season
"2007 Atlanta Falcons season")

For the 2007 season, the [Falcons](/wiki/2007_Atlanta_Falcons_season "2007
Atlanta Falcons season") were forced to start [Joey
Harrington](/wiki/Joey_Harrington "Joey Harrington") at quarterback. On
December 11, 13 games into his first NFL season as head coach, [Bobby
Petrino](/wiki/Bobby_Petrino "Bobby Petrino") resigned without notice to coach
at the [University of Arkansas](/wiki/Arkansas_Razorbacks_football "Arkansas
Razorbacks football"), leaving the beleaguered players only a note in the
locker room. Secondary Coach [Emmitt Thomas](/wiki/Emmitt_Thomas "Emmitt
Thomas") was named interim coach for the final three games of the season on
December 12. The Falcons ended the year with a dismal 4–12 record.

### 2008–2014: The Mike Smith
era[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Atlanta_Falcons&action=edit&section=9 "Edit
section: 2008–2014: The Mike Smith era")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Mike_Smith_%28American_football_coach%29_2013.jpg/220px-
Mike_Smith_%28American_football_coach%29_2013.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mike_Smith_\(American_football_coach\)_2013.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mike_Smith_\(American_football_coach\)_2013.jpg "Enlarge")

[Mike Smith](/wiki/Mike_Smith_\(American_football_coach\) "Mike Smith
\(American football coach\)")

After the tumultuous and disappointing 2007 season, the Falcons made a number
of moves, hiring a new General Manager and head coach, drafting a new starting
quarterback, and signing a starting running back.

On January 13, 2008, the Falcons named former Patriots director of college
football scouting [Thomas Dimitroff](/wiki/Thomas_Dimitroff "Thomas
Dimitroff") General Manager.[11] On January 23, [Jacksonville
Jaguars](/wiki/Jacksonville_Jaguars "Jacksonville Jaguars") defensive coach
and former linebackers coach for the 2000 Super Bowl champion Baltimore Ravens
[Mike Smith](/wiki/Mike_Smith_\(American_football_coach\) "Mike Smith
\(American football coach\)") was named the Falcons' new head coach.[12]
Chargers back-up RB [Michael
Turner](/wiki/Michael_Turner_\(American_football\) "Michael Turner \(American
football\)") agreed to a 6-year deal, $30 million deal on March 2.[13] On
April 26, [Matt Ryan](/wiki/Matt_Ryan_\(American_football\) "Matt Ryan
\(American football\)") (quarterback from [Boston
College](/wiki/Boston_College "Boston College")) was drafted third overall in
the [2008 NFL draft](/wiki/2008_NFL_draft "2008 NFL draft") by the Falcons.

#### 2008[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Atlanta_Falcons&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: 2008")]

Main article: [2008 Atlanta Falcons season](/wiki/2008_Atlanta_Falcons_season
"2008 Atlanta Falcons season")

The Falcons finished the 2008 regular season with a record of 11–5, and the #5
seed in the playoffs.[14] On December 21, 2008, Atlanta beat the Minnesota
Vikings 24–17 to clinch a wild card spot, earning a trip to the playoffs for
the first time since 2004. The Falcons would go on to lose in the wild-card
round of the 2008 NFL playoffs to the eventual NFC champion [Arizona
Cardinals](/wiki/2008_Arizona_Cardinals_season "2008 Arizona Cardinals
season"), 30–24.

Matt Ryan started all 16 games in his rookie season and was named the
Associated Press Offensive Rookie of the Year.[15] First-year head coach Mike
Smith was named 2008 NFL Coach of the Year.

#### 2009[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Atlanta_Falcons&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: 2009")]

Main article: [2009 Atlanta Falcons season](/wiki/2009_Atlanta_Falcons_season
"2009 Atlanta Falcons season")

Although they failed to make the playoffs in 2009 the team rallied to win
their final three regular season games to record back-to-back winning seasons
for the first time in franchise history. The Falcons defeated the [Tampa Bay
Buccaneers](/wiki/Tampa_Bay_Buccaneers "Tampa Bay Buccaneers") 20–10 in the
final game of the season to improve their record to 9–7.[3]

#### 2010[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Atlanta_Falcons&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: 2010")]

Main article: [2010 Atlanta Falcons season](/wiki/2010_Atlanta_Falcons_season
"2010 Atlanta Falcons season")

In 2010, with a regular season record of 13–3, the Falcons secured a third
straight winning season, their fourth overall divisional title, and the top
overall seed in the NFC playoffs; however, the Falcons were overpowered by the
eventual [Super Bowl XLV](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XLV "Super Bowl XLV") champion
[Green Bay Packers](/wiki/Green_Bay_Packers "Green Bay Packers") in the NFC
Divisional Playoffs 48–21. The Falcons scored 414 points – the fifth-most in
franchise history.[3] The team sent an NFL-high and franchise-best nine
players to the [2011 Pro Bowl](/wiki/2011_Pro_Bowl "2011 Pro
Bowl").[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_]

#### 2011[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Atlanta_Falcons&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: 2011")]

Main article: [2011 Atlanta Falcons season](/wiki/2011_Atlanta_Falcons_season
"2011 Atlanta Falcons season")

The Falcons made a surprise trade up with the [Cleveland
Browns](/wiki/Cleveland_Browns "Cleveland Browns") in the [2011 NFL
draft](/wiki/2011_NFL_draft "2011 NFL draft") to select
[Alabama](/wiki/Alabama_Crimson_Tide_football "Alabama Crimson Tide football")
wide receiver [Julio Jones](/wiki/Julio_Jones "Julio Jones") sixth overall. In
exchange, the Falcons gave up their first-, second- and fourth-round draft
picks in 2011, and their first and fourth draft picks in 2012. Jones, along
with teammates [Tony Gonzalez](/wiki/Tony_Gonzalez "Tony Gonzalez") and [Roddy
White](/wiki/Roddy_White "Roddy White"), have since been dubbed Atlanta's "Big
Three" (based on their total number of reception yards).[16] On August 30,
2011, [Sports Illustrated](/wiki/Sports_Illustrated "Sports Illustrated")
senior writer [Peter King](/wiki/Peter_King_\(sportswriter\) "Peter King
\(sportswriter\)"), who correctly predicted the 2011 Super Bowl, made his
predictions for the 2011 season and picked the Falcons to defeat the San Diego
Chargers in the 2012 Super Bowl.[17] The Falcons finished the season at 10–6,
securing the fifth seed after a Week 17 beatdown of Tampa Bay in which the
Falcons pulled their starters after leading 42–0 just 23 minutes into the
game.

The Falcons then went on to play the [New York Giants](/wiki/New_York_Giants
"New York Giants") in a 2011 NFC Wild Card Game at [MetLife
Stadium](/wiki/MetLife_Stadium "MetLife Stadium") in [East Rutherford, New
Jersey](/wiki/East_Rutherford,_New_Jersey "East Rutherford, New Jersey"). The
first half was a defensive struggle, with the first points coming off of a
safety by the Falcons, giving Atlanta a 2–0 lead. In the 2nd quarter, though,
[Eli Manning](/wiki/Eli_Manning "Eli Manning") connected with [Hakeem
Nicks](/wiki/Hakeem_Nicks "Hakeem Nicks") for a short touchdown pass to make
it 7–2 Giants heading into the 2nd half. Then the Giants took control, as
Manning threw for two more TD passes to [Mario
Manningham](/wiki/Mario_Manningham "Mario Manningham") and Nicks and the
defense completed its shutout of the Falcons to give the [New York
Giants](/wiki/New_York_Giants "New York Giants") the win, 24–2, and the
Falcons their third straight playoff loss with [Matt
Ryan](/wiki/Matt_Ryan_\(American_football\) "Matt Ryan \(American football\)")
and [Mike Smith](/wiki/Mike_Smith_\(American_football_coach\) "Mike Smith
\(American football coach\)"). After the season Defense Coordinator [Brian
VanGorder](/wiki/Brian_VanGorder "Brian VanGorder") accepted a coaching job at
[Auburn University](/wiki/Auburn_University "Auburn University"), and the
offensive coordinator [Mike Mularkey](/wiki/Mike_Mularkey "Mike Mularkey")
took the head coaching job in Jacksonville.

#### 2012[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Atlanta_Falcons&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: 2012")]

Main article: [2012 Atlanta Falcons season](/wiki/2012_Atlanta_Falcons_season
"2012 Atlanta Falcons season")

Atlanta exploded out of the gate, going a franchise best 8–0 and remaining the
last unbeaten team in the NFL that year. Their hopes to get an undefeated
season came to an end with a 27–31 loss to the division rival Saints. Julio
Jones had a remarkable second year, grabbing 10 touchdowns and 1,198 yards.
The Falcons finished the season 13–3, and clinched the number one seed in the
NFC playoffs.

The Falcons played the [Seattle Seahawks](/wiki/Seattle_Seahawks "Seattle
Seahawks") in their first playoff game. Although they went down 28–27 with
only 31 seconds left on the clock, [Matt
Ryan](/wiki/Matt_Ryan_\(American_football\) "Matt Ryan \(American football\)")
led the team to their first playoff victory, 30–28. It was the only playoff
victory in the Mike Smith era.

The Atlanta Falcons then advanced to face the [San Francisco
49ers](/wiki/San_Francisco_49ers "San Francisco 49ers"). The Falcons seized
control of the game early with a [Matt Bryant](/wiki/Matt_Bryant "Matt
Bryant") field goal, a trio of Matt Ryan touchdown passes caught by [Julio
Jones](/wiki/Julio_Jones "Julio Jones") and [Tony
Gonzalez](/wiki/Tony_Gonzalez "Tony Gonzalez") coupled with outstanding
defensive play. By the end of the half, the score was 24–14. The tides of the
game began to shift in the second half as the 49ers rallied back with a pair
of [Frank Gore](/wiki/Frank_Gore "Frank Gore") touchdown runs. Atlanta's
offense attempted to reply but were ultimately shut down by the 49er defense.
A few series later, late in the 4th quarter with little time remaining,
Atlanta found themselves in a 4th and 4 situation at the 10-yard line. The
Falcons needed just 10 more yards to secure victory and advance to their first
Super Bowl berth in 14 years. Matt Ryan fired a pass to [Roddy
White](/wiki/Roddy_White "Roddy White") which was ultimately broken up by
inside linebacker [NaVorro Bowman](/wiki/NaVorro_Bowman "NaVorro Bowman"),
resulting in a 28–24 defeat.

#### 2013[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Atlanta_Falcons&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: 2013")]

Main article: [2013 Atlanta Falcons season](/wiki/2013_Atlanta_Falcons_season
"2013 Atlanta Falcons season")

Following the success of the previous season, the Falcons were an expected
Super Bowl contender. However, injuries hampered the team's performance and
the team finished the season 4–12. With that, the streak of consecutive
winning seasons came to an end and [Mike
Smith](/wiki/Mike_Smith_\(American_football_coach\) "Mike Smith \(American
football coach\)") had his first losing season as a head coach. [Tony
Gonzalez](/wiki/Tony_Gonzalez "Tony Gonzalez"), in his final season in the
NFL, was selected to the [2014 Pro Bowl](/wiki/2014_Pro_Bowl "2014 Pro Bowl")
as a starter representing Team Rice. Following the conclusion of the 2012
season, director of player personnel [Les Snead](/wiki/Les_Snead "Les Snead")
departed the team to join the [St. Louis Rams](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Rams "Los
Angeles Rams") and [Dave Caldwell](/wiki/Dave_Caldwell "Dave Caldwell"),
assistant to general manager [Thomas Dimitroff](/wiki/Thomas_Dimitroff "Thomas
Dimitroff"), left the team to join the [Jacksonville
Jaguars](/wiki/Jacksonville_Jaguars "Jacksonville Jaguars"). Scott Pioli,
former GM of the [New England Patriots](/wiki/New_England_Patriots "New
England Patriots"), was announced as the Falcons' new assistant GM. Mike Smith
was given a one-year extension on his contract as head coach. The Falcons had
the 6th overall pick in the [2014 NFL draft](/wiki/2014_NFL_draft "2014 NFL
draft") with which they selected [Jake Matthews](/wiki/Jake_Matthews "Jake
Matthews"), who played as offensive tackle for [Texas A&M](/wiki/Texas_A%26M
"Texas A&M").

#### 2014[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Atlanta_Falcons&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: 2014")]

Main article: [2014 Atlanta Falcons season](/wiki/2014_Atlanta_Falcons_season
"2014 Atlanta Falcons season")

Despite having another rough season, the Falcons still had an opportunity to
qualify for the playoffs at the end of the regular season. The Falcons hosted
the [Carolina Panthers](/wiki/Carolina_Panthers "Carolina Panthers") in their
regular season finale, with the winners clinching the [NFC
South](/wiki/NFC_South "NFC South") division. Unfortunately, the Falcons lost
in a 34–3 blowout as [Matt Ryan](/wiki/Matt_Ryan_\(American_football\) "Matt
Ryan \(American football\)") threw two interceptions that were returned for
touchdowns and got sacked six times. The Falcons finished the season 6–10,
marking the second consecutive losing season for the team.[18] The following
day, [Mike Smith](/wiki/Mike_Smith_\(American_football_coach\) "Mike Smith
\(American football coach\)") was fired after seven seasons as head coach.[19]
The Falcons would soon hire [Seattle Seahawks](/wiki/Seattle_Seahawks "Seattle
Seahawks") defensive coordinator [Dan
Quinn](/wiki/Dan_Quinn_\(American_football\) "Dan Quinn \(American
football\)") as the team's 16th head coach.[20] The Falcons had the 8th
overall pick in the [2015 NFL draft](/wiki/2015_NFL_draft "2015 NFL draft")
with which they selected [Vic Beasley](/wiki/Vic_Beasley "Vic Beasley"), a
defensive end from Clemson University.[21]

### 2015–present: The Dan Quinn
era[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Atlanta_Falcons&action=edit&section=17 "Edit
section: 2015–present: The Dan Quinn era")]

#### 2015[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Atlanta_Falcons&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: 2015")]

Main article: [2015 Atlanta Falcons season](/wiki/2015_Atlanta_Falcons_season
"2015 Atlanta Falcons season")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Dan_Quinn_2015_intro_press_conference.jpg/220px-
Dan_Quinn_2015_intro_press_conference.jpg)](/wiki/File:Dan_Quinn_2015_intro_press_conference.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Dan_Quinn_2015_intro_press_conference.jpg "Enlarge")

[Dan Quinn](/wiki/Dan_Quinn_\(American_football\) "Dan Quinn \(American
football\)")

In February 2015, the team was investigated by the NFL for alleged use of
artificial crowd noise in the Georgia Dome.[22] The Falcons lost a [2016 NFL
Draft](/wiki/2016_NFL_Draft "2016 NFL Draft") selection as a result of the
league's investigation.[23]

Dan Quinn's first season saw a 5–0 start, the team's best start in four years.
They would then struggle throughout the rest of the season by losing 8 of
their last 11 games, resulting in an 8–8 record. They did, however, give the
Panthers their only regular season loss. The Falcons used their first-round
pick in the [2016 NFL Draft](/wiki/2016_NFL_Draft "2016 NFL Draft") on safety
[Keanu Neal](/wiki/Keanu_Neal "Keanu Neal") from the [University of
Florida](/wiki/University_of_Florida "University of Florida").

#### 2016[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Atlanta_Falcons&action=edit&section=19
"Edit section: 2016")]

Main article: [2016 Atlanta Falcons season](/wiki/2016_Atlanta_Falcons_season
"2016 Atlanta Falcons season")

In the Falcons' 25th and final season in the Georgia Dome, Atlanta lost their
Week 1 game to the Buccaneers 24–31. The Falcons would then win their next
four including one over the Panthers, when the franchise set new records. Matt
Ryan threw for 503 yards, and Julio Jones caught twelve passes for 300 yards.
With a 41–13 thrashing of the [San Francisco 49ers](/wiki/San_Francisco_49ers
"San Francisco 49ers") in Week 15, the Falcons improved to 9–5 and secured
their first winning season since 2012. One week later, the Falcons defeated
the Panthers in [Charlotte, North Carolina](/wiki/Charlotte,_North_Carolina
"Charlotte, North Carolina") and clinched their first NFC South division title
since 2012. In their last regular season game at the Georgia Dome, the Falcons
defeated the [New Orleans Saints](/wiki/New_Orleans_Saints "New Orleans
Saints"), and secured an 11–5 record and a first round bye.

In the divisional round of the playoffs, Atlanta defeated the Seahawks 36–20
in the Georgia Dome, and hosted their last game at the Dome against the [Green
Bay Packers](/wiki/Green_Bay_Packers "Green Bay Packers") in the [NFC
Championship Game](/wiki/NFC_Championship_Game "NFC Championship Game") on
January 22, 2017. The Falcons defeated the Packers 44–21 to advance to [Super
Bowl LI](/wiki/Super_Bowl_LI "Super Bowl LI") as the NFC champions. Atlanta
was up 28–3 late in the third quarter, and the [New England
Patriots](/wiki/New_England_Patriots "New England Patriots") scored 31
unanswered points, with the last 6 in the first-ever overtime in the Super
Bowl. The Patriots' 25-point comeback was the largest in Super Bowl
history.[24]

In 2016, the Falcons scored 540 points in the regular season, the seventh-most
in NFL history, tied with the [Greatest Show on
Turf](/wiki/Greatest_Show_on_Turf "Greatest Show on Turf") (the [2000 St.
Louis Rams](/wiki/2000_St._Louis_Rams_season "2000 St. Louis Rams
season")).[25] However, the Falcons defense gave up 406 points, 27th in the
league.[26]

#### 2017[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Atlanta_Falcons&action=edit&section=20
"Edit section: 2017")]

Main article: [2017 Atlanta Falcons season](/wiki/2017_Atlanta_Falcons_season
"2017 Atlanta Falcons season")

The Falcons moved into their new home, the [Mercedes-Benz
Stadium](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_Stadium "Mercedes-Benz Stadium"), this season.
Their first game ever played at the new stadium was a preseason loss to the
[Arizona Cardinals](/wiki/Arizona_Cardinals "Arizona Cardinals"). The first
regular season game at the new stadium was a rematch of the 2016–17 NFC
Championship, with Atlanta defeating Green Bay 34–23.

## Stadiums[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Atlanta_Falcons&action=edit&section=21
"Edit section: Stadiums")]

Main article: [Mercedes-Benz Stadium](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_Stadium "Mercedes-
Benz Stadium")

The Falcons have called only two stadiums home in their 51 years of existence,
and will have a third home in their history in the late summer of 2017. The
first was the [Atlanta–Fulton County
Stadium](/wiki/Atlanta%E2%80%93Fulton_County_Stadium "Atlanta–Fulton County
Stadium"), sharing with the [Atlanta Braves](/wiki/Atlanta_Braves "Atlanta
Braves") [Major League Baseball](/wiki/Major_League_Baseball "Major League
Baseball") team until 1991. In 1992, the [Georgia Dome](/wiki/Georgia_Dome
"Georgia Dome") was built, and the Falcons played there from its opening to
the 2016 season. The Dome has been frequently used for [college
football](/wiki/College_football "College football"), including [Georgia
State](/wiki/Georgia_State_Panthers_football "Georgia State Panthers
football") football and college bowl games such as the [Peach
Bowl](/wiki/Peach_Bowl "Peach Bowl").

In an effort to replace the aging Georgia Dome and potentially host a future
[Super Bowl](/wiki/Super_Bowl "Super Bowl"), team owner Arthur Blank proposed
a deal with the city of Atlanta to build a new state-of-the-art stadium not
far from where the Georgia Dome is located. Blank will contribute $800 million
and the city of Atlanta will contribute an additional $200 million via bonds
backed by the city's hotel/motel tax towards the construction of a retractable
roof stadium. Blank will contribute additional money for cost overruns if it
is needed. The team will provide up to $50 million towards infrastructure
costs that weren't included in the construction budget and to retire the
remaining debt on the Georgia Dome. In addition, Blank's foundation and the
city will each provide $15 million for development in surrounding
neighborhoods. Though the total cost of the stadium was initially estimated to
be around $1 billion,[27] the total cost was revised to $1.5 billion according
to Blank.[28] In March 2013, the Atlanta City Council voted 11–4 in favor of
building the stadium.[29] The retractable roof [Mercedes-Benz
Stadium](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_Stadium "Mercedes-Benz Stadium") broke ground in
May 2014, and will begin hosting the Falcons' and [Atlanta
United](/wiki/Atlanta_United_FC "Atlanta United FC")'s [Major League
Soccer](/wiki/Major_League_Soccer "Major League Soccer") games in 2017.

## Logo and
uniforms[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Atlanta_Falcons&action=edit&section=22
"Edit section: Logo and uniforms")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/1/11/NFC-Throwback2-Uniform-
ATL.PNG/150px-NFC-Throwback2-Uniform-ATL.PNG)](/wiki/File:NFC-
Throwback2-Uniform-ATL.PNG)

[](/wiki/File:NFC-Throwback2-Uniform-ATL.PNG "Enlarge")

Atlanta Falcons uniform: 1971–1989

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/3/35/NFC-Throwback-Uniform-
ATL.PNG/150px-NFC-Throwback-Uniform-ATL.PNG)](/wiki/File:NFC-Throwback-
Uniform-ATL.PNG)

[](/wiki/File:NFC-Throwback-Uniform-ATL.PNG "Enlarge")

Atlanta Falcons uniform: 1997–2002

The Atlanta Falcons' colors are red, black, silver and white.[30] When the
team debuted in [1966](/wiki/1966_Atlanta_Falcons_season "1966 Atlanta Falcons
season"), the Falcons wore red helmets with a black falcon crest logo. In the
center of the helmet was a center black stripe surrounded by two gold stripes
and two white stripes. These colors represented the two college rival schools
in the state of Georgia; rival schools [Georgia Tech Yellow
Jackets](/wiki/Georgia_Tech_Yellow_Jackets "Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets")
(White and Gold) and the [Georgia Bulldogs](/wiki/Georgia_Bulldogs "Georgia
Bulldogs") (Red and Black). Although the gold was later taken out, the white
remains to this day. They wore white pants and either black or white jerseys.
At first, the falcon crest logo was also put on the jersey sleeves, but it was
replaced by a red and white stripe pattern four years later. They switched
from black to red jerseys in 1971, and the club began to wear silver pants in
1978.

A prototype white helmet was developed for the team prior to the [1974
season](/wiki/1974_Atlanta_Falcons_season "1974 Atlanta Falcons season") but
was never worn.

In [1990](/wiki/1990_Atlanta_Falcons_season "1990 Atlanta Falcons season"),
the uniform design changed to black helmets, silver pants, and either black or
white jerseys. The numbers on the white jerseys were black, but were changed
to red in [1997](/wiki/1997_Atlanta_Falcons_season "1997 Atlanta Falcons
season"). (The red numerals could be seen on the away jerseys briefly in
1990.)

Both the logo and uniforms changed in [2003](/wiki/2003_Atlanta_Falcons_season
"2003 Atlanta Falcons season"). The logo was redesigned with red and silver
accents to depict a more powerful, aggressive falcon, which now more closely
resembles the capital letter _F_.[10]

Although the Falcons still wore black helmets, the new uniforms featured
jerseys and pants with red trim down the sides. The uniform design consisted
of either black or white jerseys, and either black or white pants. During that
same year, a red alternate jersey with black trim was also introduced. The
Falcons also started wearing black cleats with these uniforms.[31]

In [2004](/wiki/2004_Atlanta_Falcons_season "2004 Atlanta Falcons season"),
the red jerseys became the primary jerseys, and the black ones became the
alternate, both worn with white pants. In select road games, the Falcons wear
black pants with white jerseys. The Falcons wore an all-black combination for
home games against their archrivals, the [New Orleans
Saints](/wiki/New_Orleans_Saints "New Orleans Saints"), winning the first two
contests (24–21 in [2004](/wiki/2004_NFL_season "2004 NFL season") and 36–17
in [2005](/wiki/2005_NFL_season "2005 NFL season")), but losing 31–13 in
[2006](/wiki/2006_NFL_season "2006 NFL season"). The Falcons wore the all
black combination against the New Orleans Saints for four straight seasons
starting in 2004, With the last time being in 2007, losing 34–14. They wore
the combination again in 2006, against the [Tampa Bay
Buccaneers](/wiki/Tampa_Bay_Buccaneers "Tampa Bay Buccaneers") in Week 2. The
Falcons won that game, 14–3. The Falcons also wore their all-black uniform in
2007 against the New York Giants, and in 2008 against the Carolina Panthers
and against the Tampa Bay Buccaneers (for the second time).

In the 1980s, the Falcons wore their white uniforms at home most of the time
because of the heat. When the Falcons started playing in a dome, the team
switched to their dark uniforms for home games but have worn their white
uniforms at home a few times since switching to the dome. It was announced at
the 2009 state of the franchise meeting that the Falcons would wear 1966
throwback uniforms for a couple games during the 2009 season. The Atlanta
Falcons wore 1966 throwback jerseys for two home games in 2009 – against the
Carolina Panthers on September 20 and against the Tampa Bay Buccaneers on
November 29. The Falcons won both of those games. They donned the throwbacks
again for 2 games in 2010, against Baltimore and San Francisco, winning both
of those games as well.

## Rivalries[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Atlanta_Falcons&action=edit&section=23
"Edit section: Rivalries")]

### New Orleans
Saints[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Atlanta_Falcons&action=edit&section=24 "Edit
section: New Orleans Saints")]

[![\[icon\]](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/20px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg) | **This section needs expansion**. Main article: [Falcons–Saints rivalry](/wiki/Falcons%E2%80%93Saints_rivalry
"Falcons–Saints rivalry")

In every season except for their debut season, the Falcons have shared a
division with the [New Orleans Saints](/wiki/New_Orleans_Saints "New Orleans
Saints") (first the NFC West, and now the NFC South). Over this time, a heated
rivalry has developed between the two cities' franchises. Atlanta leads the
series 51–45.

### Carolina
Panthers[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Atlanta_Falcons&action=edit&section=25
"Edit section: Carolina Panthers")]

[![\[icon\]](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/20px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg) | **This section needs expansion**. You can help by [adding to it](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Atlanta_Falcons&action=edit&section=). _(June 2017)_  
---|---  
  
Main article: [Falcons–Panthers
rivalry](/wiki/Falcons%E2%80%93Panthers_rivalry "Falcons–Panthers rivalry")

In addition, the Falcons share a similar, yet smaller, rivalry with the
[Carolina Panthers](/wiki/Carolina_Panthers "Carolina Panthers"), with both
teams having been in the [NFC West](/wiki/NFC_West "NFC West") from the
Panthers' founding in 1995 to the NFL realignment in 2002, where they have
been in the [NFC South](/wiki/NFC_South "NFC South") since then. The Falcons
lead the series 27–17.

Honor[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Atlanta_Falcons&action=edit&section=36 "Edit
section: Ring of Honor")]

The Atlanta Falcons organization does not officially retire jersey numbers,
but considers certain players' jerseys worthy of being honored. The Falcons
Ring of Honor, which is featured in the rafters of the Georgia Dome, honors
individual players.[35]

In their history, the Atlanta Falcons have had 15 head coaches.[36]

---|---|---|---  
[Norb Hecker](/wiki/Norb_Hecker "Norb Hecker") | 1966–1968 | 4–26–1 (.129) | Fired after three games in 1968.  
[Norm Van Brocklin](/wiki/Norm_Van_Brocklin "Norm Van Brocklin") | 1968–1974 | 39–48–3 (.433) | Fired after eight games in 1974.  
[Marion Campbell](/wiki/Marion_Campbell "Marion Campbell") | 1974–1976 | 6–19 (.240) | Fired after five games in 1976.  
[Pat Peppler](/wiki/Pat_Peppler "Pat Peppler") | 1976 | 3–6 (.333) | Interim head coach.  
[Leeman Bennett](/wiki/Leeman_Bennett "Leeman Bennett") | 1977–1982 | 46–41 (.529) |   
[Dan Henning](/wiki/Dan_Henning "Dan Henning") | 1983–1986 | 22–41–1 (.344) |   
Marion Campbell | 1987–1989 | 11–36 (.234) | Retired after 12 games in 1989.  
[Jim Hanifan](/wiki/Jim_Hanifan "Jim Hanifan") | 1989 | 0–4 (.000) | Interim head coach.  
[Jerry Glanville](/wiki/Jerry_Glanville "Jerry Glanville") | 1990–1993 | 27–37 (.422) |   
[June Jones](/wiki/June_Jones "June Jones") | 1994–1996 | 19–29 (.396) |   
[Dan Reeves](/wiki/Dan_Reeves "Dan Reeves") | 1997–2003 | 49–59–1 (.450) |   
[Wade Phillips](/wiki/Wade_Phillips "Wade Phillips") | 2003 | 2–1 (.667) | Interim head coach.  
[Jim Mora](/wiki/Jim_L._Mora "Jim L. Mora") | 2004–2006 | 26–22 (.542) |   
[Bobby Petrino](/wiki/Bobby_Petrino "Bobby Petrino") | 2007 | 3–10 (.231) | Resigned after 13 games to take over [Arkansas Razorbacks](/wiki/Arkansas_Razorbacks "Arkansas Razorbacks").  
[Emmitt Thomas](/wiki/Emmitt_Thomas "Emmitt Thomas") | 2007 | 1–2 (.333) | Interim head coach.  
[Mike Smith](/wiki/Mike_Smith_\(American_football_coach\) "Mike Smith \(American football coach\)") | 2008–2014 | 66–46 (.589) |   
[Dan Quinn](/wiki/Dan_Quinn_\(American_football\) "Dan Quinn \(American football\)") | 2015–present | 19–13 (.594) |

## Radio and
television[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Atlanta_Falcons&action=edit&section=43
"Edit section: Radio and television")]

Falcons' flagship radio station is [WZGC](/wiki/WZGC_\(FM\) "WZGC \(FM\)")
92.9 The Game.[37] [Wes Durham](/wiki/Wes_Durham "Wes Durham"), son of
longtime [North Carolina Tar Heels](/wiki/North_Carolina_Tar_Heels "North
Carolina Tar Heels") voice [Woody Durham](/wiki/Woody_Durham "Woody Durham"),
is the Falcons' play-by-play announcer, with former Atlanta Falcons QB and pro
football veteran, [Dave Archer](/wiki/David_Archer_\(quarterback\) "David
Archer \(quarterback\)") serving as color commentator.

In 2014, [The CW](/wiki/The_CW "The CW") owned-and-operated station
[WUPA](/wiki/WUPA "WUPA") became the official television station of the
Falcons, gaining rights to its preseason games, which are produced by [CBS
Sports](/wiki/CBS_Sports "CBS Sports").[38]

In the regular season, the team's games are seen on Fox's O&O affiliate
[WAGA](/wiki/WAGA-TV "WAGA-TV"). When the Falcons challenge an AFC team, CBS
affiliate [WGCL](/wiki/WGCL-TV "WGCL-TV") will air those games while Sunday
night games are televised on [WXIA](/wiki/WXIA-TV "WXIA-TV"), the local NBC
affiliate.
